I've spent the past 4 years learning Turkish, and Turkish and Japanese have quite a few similarities mostly with grammar/sentence structure but also how there are some things they say that is really hard to translate to or express in English (moreso than differences between Spanish and English), so maybe I'll add in my two-cents.In other cases outside of anime, some people are already outraged over this kind of situation as "cultural erasion".Just as a hypothetical example, if we took Turkish historical fiction and instead of using accurate terms like "sultan", "padishah", etc. and just used European terms like "king" it would not be an accurate translation even though you might think it to be more accessible to Western audiences (Turkish even has the word for "king" (kral) in it to refer specifically to the European context because it's conceptually different from a sultan or padishah). Same with other honorifics like "bey", "efendi", "teyze", "amca", which I guess could be translated to English "sir", "lord", "aunt", "uncle", etc but those words sound very inaccurate and weird to me in a Turkish context while they're translated to English.With the new Disney movie "Raya" coming out I've already seen complaints that the movie studio has "diluted South-East Asian cultures in order to appeal to Westerners". The idea that he wants everything to be 100% English and doesn't want readers to learn Japanese terms just really sits wrong with me, like you said elitist but also maybe eurocentric? Like 'dumb Westerners' have to or should be coddled from outside cultures. Idk though.

Give your opinion on the subject matter.

When it comes to female food youTubers, the opposite is the problem. Those I stumbled upon didn't go on tangents. If anything they were too focussed on the recipe and were about as fun to watch as a lecture on techniques to watch paint dry. Those female foodTubers treated the camera like a dead object - which it admittedly is - but treating it as such creates a barrier between the audience and the people in the video. Also: They're pretty much interchangeable.  Male Foodtuber treat the camera more like a pal they're having over to do some cooking. Helen Rennie comes across like teachers. Barry Lewis comes across like the slightly whacky friend that's a blast to be around and happen to learn somethin in the process. If you're looking for information on how to make a certain dish Helen Rennie is the better choice. But that's not why I watch cooking videos on youTube. I'm looking for ideas, inspiration and to be entertained in the process. And while I most definitely wouldn't even want to replicate most the stuff Barry Lewis cooks, he did give me ideas and I think he's fun to watch. I think this difference in approach - instructor vs. pal - is what makes male foodtubers more successful than female ones.

Period.Cycle threshold (CT) is not only arbitrary, it’s meaningless, and an abuse of Kary Mullis’ amplification tool.CT is an arbitrary and meaningless number of amplifications above an equally arbitrary and meaningless lower number of amplifications referred to as “background level”…https://www.wvdl.wisc.edu/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/WVDL.Info_.PCR_Ct_Values1.pdfThe PCR amplifies nucleotide sequences exponentially…https://www.khanacademy.org/science/ap-biology/gene-expression-and-regulation/biotechnology/a/polymerase-chain-reaction-pcr…up to approximately 40 amplifications,[1] therefore any differences between the CT level and background level are meaningless. A CT of 21x merely means there were 21 amplifications. A CT of 30 has 30 amplifications. A CT of 21x simply means the nucleotide sequence was amplified 21 times, not that there is “strong positive reactions indicative of abundant target nucleic acid”…https://www.wvdl.wisc.edu/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/WVDL.Info_.PCR_Ct_Values1.pdf------------------------[1] Thereafter amplification growth is less than exponential.
